topic_rationale: Classic cause of nephrotic syndrome in children/young adults, excellent teaching case for proteinuria workup

explanations.tile_0: Young age (8 years old) is classic for minimal change disease, which is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children.
explanations.tile_1: Facial swelling, especially periorbital edema, is often the first sign parents notice in pediatric nephrotic syndrome.
explanations.tile_2: Massive proteinuria (4+ on dipstick) is the hallmark of nephrotic syndrome, defined as >3.5g protein per day.
explanations.tile_3: Severe hypoalbuminemia (<2.5 g/dL) occurs due to urinary protein losses and contributes to edema formation.
explanations.tile_4: Hypercholesterolemia is part of the classic nephrotic syndrome tetrad, caused by increased hepatic lipoprotein synthesis.
explanations.tile_5: Light microscopy shows normal-appearing glomeruli in minimal change disease, distinguishing it from other causes.
explanations.tile_6: Electron microscopy reveals podocyte foot process effacement (fusion), the pathognomonic finding in minimal change disease.
explanations.tile_7: Excellent response to corticosteroids (>90% in children) is characteristic and helps confirm the diagnosis.
explanations.tile_8: Absence of immune deposits on immunofluorescence distinguishes minimal change disease from immune-mediated glomerulonephritis.
